description.narrative:
The inland fresh waters of Cambodia flow from upstream of Mekong River border with Laos PDR downstream, to the Tonle Sap (Great Lake) via the Tonle-Bassac River and then to the sea through the Mekong delta in Vietnam. The water serves the foundation for agricultural activities, sustains biodiversity and ecosystem services, and food production. The construction of mega-hydropower dams upstreamof the Mekong including an operational hydro-power dam- Lower Sesan 2 - in the 3S region (a major tributary of the Mekong River) are threatening the natural flow regime of the Mekong River including the unique annual flow reversal phenomena of the Tonle Sap Great Lake – threatens the freshwater fisheries and ecosystems, as well as the multipurpose water consumption of local people in the region.
Oxfam in Cambodia through Inclusion Project Phase 2 (IP II) works in partnership with our strategic partner in the Lower Mekong, namely Northeastern Rural Development Organization (NRD), MVI and former unrestricted funded partner, 3SPN, to continue to build capacity and increase number women leaders to represent their community to voice their issues and concerns to state and non-state actors for better governance of water resources in the Mekong and its tributaries.
Oxfam in Cambodia also works closely and supports the NGO Forum on Cambodia (NGOF) that works with and and coordinates with the River Coalition of Cambodia (RCC) and its members to strengthen community’s voices and solidarity and increase CSO’s cooperation and engagement to influence water governance policy and decision making at national and regional levels.
Furthermore, Oxfam in Cambodia works with the Fishery Action Coalition Team (FACT)to strengthen the voices of fishery resource dependent communities through connecting and networking of fishing community representatives across the country to join the national fishery network namely “Cambodia Fishery Network” to influence fishery policy decisions and practice for better governance of water and fisheries resources especially in the Mekong and Tonle Sap/Great Lake.
Oxfam also funds EnergyLab for the raising awareness with CSOs and Youth to influence renewable energy policy promoting diversified and sustainable energy sources.
In addition, Oxfam in Cambodia and its IP2 partners, non-funded partners and private sector actors continue to convene dialogue events introducing sustainable renewable alternative options and best practice for sustainable energy development with an aim toward aore informed, transparent and accountable water resource governance (WRG) and RE infrastructure decision making in the Lower Mekong and Tributaries

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education forall, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam established this country office to support local organizations and projects. Through this local office Oxfam Novib directly contributes towards this project#s implementation.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation
